Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Summer School on Active Complex Matter (Cargese, France, July 12-23, 2016)

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Marchetti, M. Cristina
Proposal Number: 1632054
Institution: Syracuse University
Title: Conference: Summer School on Active Complex Matter (Cargese, France, July 12-23, 2016)


This is a project to support expenses related to the registration and travel of young scientists and students from the US to attend the summer school on "Active Complex Matter," to be held in Cargese (Corsica Island, France) in July, 2016. About 15 US participants (10 graduate students and 5 post-docs) are expected to be supported through this grant, who would not otherwise be able to attend.

Active fluids are those where the presence of active particles that can self-assemble, or can move and pack in different ways, give different macroscopic properties to the fluid. The focus of the summer school will be on areas that are very research active, including microorganism swimming, collective cell behavior, and blood flow. The aims of the proposed workshop are to i) address challenges in the modeling of active (synthetic, biomimetic, and living) matter, ii) discuss approaches to overcome these challenges, and iii) to educate and inform young scientists (mainly graduate students), who will be attending not only lectures on techniques and fundamentals, but also seminars on current research topics given by internationally known experts in the field, from the US and from around the world. The conference has a strong interdisciplinary character involving researchers from different disciplines (physics, engineering, applied mathematics, biology) as well as different generations (expert senior scientists and students).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The international summer school “Active Complex Matter” provided  a forum for discussion about the challenges and approaches in modeling flows of active fluids. It fostered interactions between different disciplines (physics, engineering, applied mathematics, biology and medical science) as well as different generations (expert senior scientists and students). The school attracted 30 world renowned researchers (most of them from US) to give lectures and talks. The school was held for a 13-day period, with lectures on weekday mornings and afternoons. The school attendance was limited to no more than 100 in order to preserve an informal atmosphere, in which the participants ask questions and take part in the discussion. The $20,000 award partially covered the registration fees and travel expenses of 12 graduate students and post-docs from US; 2 of  them are female and  2 minority.

Active matter a new, rapidly evolving area of research in complex fluids and soft condensed matter physics. The school contributed to the advancement of research and educational activities in the field of non-equilibrium soft- and bio-matter in multiple directions. First, the school broadened the students' appreciation for and interest in the field while also strengthening them technically. Second, the school fostered the formation of international and interdisciplinary collaborations that facilitate communication among scientists and engineers in different research and geographic areas.

The school was also supported by CNRS, DEUTSCH-FRANZÖSISCHE HOCHSCHULE, Institute of Scientific Studies (Cargese, France), University Joseph Fourier (Grenoble. France)
